customer_name: City of Kansas City, MO Parks and Recreation
customer_addr:
4701 E. Gregory Blvd

site_name: City of Kansas City, MO Parks and Recreation

citations.narrative:
* The contingency plan offered for review for 19 exotic animals and 11 birds was incomplete at time of inspection. The
negative effects of emergencies or natural disaster on the animal’s health can be stressful, causing potential injury.
Contingency plans show that the facility is prepared for unexpectant events, which helps to reduce risks when
emergencies or natural disasters occur. The applicant must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide
for the humane handling, treatment, transportation, housing, and care of their animals in the event of an emergency or
disaster.

* Two holes were observed in the netting located at the top of an outdoor enclosure containing four flighted birds. The
flighted birds consisted of one Turkey Vulture, One American Kestrel, One Great Horned Owl and one Red-Tailed Hawk.
The two holes were estimated to be a foot in diameter. Birds that are not securely contained in their enclosure can
escape, become entrapped or become injured. The applicant must ensure that primary enclosures are constructed and
maintained so that it will contain the birds securely.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
* No written environmental enhancement plan for 11 birds was available at the time of inspection. The plan at a minimum
must address social grouping, environmental enrichment, special considerations, restraint devices and any exemptions.
This plan shall promote the psychological well-being of birds. The physical environment in the primary enclosures must be
enriched by providing a means of expressing non injurious species-typical activities. Species differences should be
considered when determining the type or methods of environmental enhancement. Lack of environmental enhancement
could lead to abnormal behavior patterns affecting the bird’s mental and emotional health. Applicant must develop,
document, and follow a species-appropriate plan for environment enhancement adequate to promote the psychological
well-being of birds. This plan shall be made available to APHIS upon request. The environmental enhancement plan must
be approved by the attending veterinarian.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class C license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 12/3/2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and
must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.134(a) 
   
Contingency planning. 
* The contingency plan offered for review for 19 exotic animals and 11 birds was incomplete at time of inspection. The 
negative effects of emergencies or natural disaster on the animal’s health can be stressful, causing potential injury. 
Contingency plans show that the facility is prepared for unexpectant events, which helps to reduce risks when 
emergencies or natural disasters occur. The applicant must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide 
for the humane handling, treatment, transportation, housing, and care of their animals in the event of an emergency or 
disaster. 
3.153(a)(1)(iii) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
* Two holes were observed in the netting located at the top of an outdoor enclosure containing four flighted birds. The 
flighted birds consisted of one Turkey Vulture, One American Kestrel, One Great Horned Owl and one Red-Tailed Hawk. 
The two holes were estimated to be a foot in diameter. Birds that are not securely contained in their enclosure can 
escape, become entrapped or become injured. The applicant must ensure that primary enclosures are constructed and 
maintained so that it will contain the birds securely. 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
* No written environmental enhancement plan for 11 birds was available at the time of inspection. The plan at a minimum 
must address social grouping, environmental enrichment, special considerations, restraint devices and any exemptions. 
This plan shall promote the psychological well-being of birds. The physical environment in the primary enclosures must be 
enriched by providing a means of expressing non injurious species-typical activities. Species differences should be 
considered when determining the type or methods of environmental enhancement. Lack of environmental enhancement 
could lead to abnormal behavior patterns affecting the bird’s mental and emotional health. Applicant must develop, 
document, and follow a species-appropriate plan for environment enhancement adequate to promote the psychological 
well-being of birds. This plan shall be made available to APHIS upon request. The environmental enhancement plan must 
be approved by the attending veterinarian.

This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class C license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 12/3/2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and 
must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
